review.title: Rule Based Transliteration Scheme for English to Punjabi
review.abstract: Machine Transliteration has come out to be an emerging and a very important research area in the field of machine translation. Transliteration basically aims to preserve the phonological structure of words. Proper transliteration of name entities plays a very significant role in improving the quality of machine translation. In this paper we are doing machine transliteration for English-Punjabi language pair using rule based approach. We have constructed some rules for syllabification. Syllabification is the process to extract or separate the syllable from the words. In this we are calculating the probabilities for name entities (Proper names and location). For those words which do not come under the category of name entities, separate probabilities are being calculated by using relative frequency through a statistical machine translation toolkit known as MOSES. Using these probabilities we are transliterating our input text from English to Punjabi.

sections.text: DOI: 10.5121 / ijnlc.2013.2207 67Machine transliteration has proven to be an emerging and very important area of research in the field of machine translation. Transliteration is essentially aimed at preserving the phonological structure of words. Correct transliteration of name units plays a very important role in improving the quality of machine translation. In this essay, we perform machine transliteration for the English-Punjabi language pair using a rules-based approach. We have established some rules for syllabification. Syllabification is the process of extracting or separating the syllable from the words.

sections.heading: KEYWORDS
sections.text: Machine translation, machine transliteration, name recognition, syllabification.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Machine transliteration plays a very important role in gathering interlingual information. The term "entity of the name" is widely used in the processing of natural language.Name recognition has many applications in the field of natural language processing, such as information extraction, i.e. extraction of structured text from unstructured text, classification of data, and answering questions. In this essay, we only emphasize the transliteration of proper names and places with a statistical approach. The process of transliterating a word from its native language into a foreign language is called forward transliteration, and the reverse process is called backward transliteration.This essay deals with the problem of forward transliteration, i.e. from English to Punjabi. For example, "silver" in English is translated into "instead of" forward transliteration "into Punjabi. Here, our main goal is to develop a transliteration system that can be used to translate the name units, as well as the name sliteration of the target language.

sections.heading: 2. RELATED WORK
sections.text: A lot of work has been done in the field of machine transliteration. Kamal Deep and Goyal [1] have addressed the problem of transliteration Punjabi to the English language with a rules-based approach. The proposed transliteration scheme uses grapheme-based method to model the transliteration problem. This technique has shown that transliteration in WX notation brings improved results over UTF notation by presenting the English-Hindi corpus (of Indian names) with the use of statistical machine translation in different notations. In this paper, they have shown that transliteration in WX notation brings improved results over UTF notation by using the English-Hindi corpus (of Indian names) with phrase-based machine translation.

sections.heading: 3. ANALYSIS OF ENGLISH AND PUNJABI SCRIPT
sections.text: Punjabi is an ancient and Indo-Aryan language that is mainly used in the regions of Punjab. It is one of the 14 most widespread languages in the world. Its script is Gurumukhi, which is based on Devanagri. Punjabi is one of the Indian languages and official language of Punjab. Along with Punjab, it is also spoken in neighboring areas such as Haryana and Delhi. There are 19 vowels (10 independent vowels and 9 dependent vowels) and 41 consonants in the Punjab language. English, on the other hand, is based on Roman script. It is one of the six international languages of the United Nations. There are 26 letters in English. Of these, 21 are consonants and 5 vowels.

sections.heading: 4. METHODOLOGY AND EXPERIMENTAL SETUP
sections.text: In our work we use a statistical approach to transliteration, i.e. we train and test our model with the help of the MOSES toolkit. With the help of GIZA + + we have calculated translation probabilities based on probability of relativity. In the construction of our rules we use the approach of syllable formation. The syllable is a combination of vowel and consonant pairs such as V, VC, VCC, CVC, CCVC and CVCC. Almost all languages have VC, CV or CVC structures, so we use vowels and consonants as basic phonation unit.Some possible rules that we have constructed for syllabification are presented in [Table 1: Possible combinations for syllable Structures].

sections.heading: V=Vowel, C=Consonant
sections.text: If we have a word P, it is represented as a syllable in the form of {p1, p2, p3.... pn}, where p1, p2.. pn are the individual syllables.

sections.heading: 5. EVALUATION AND RESULTS
sections.text: We used a corpus of 1500 sentences of 15982 words, including 45% bearers of names, i.e. 7192 proper names, places, organization and date and time, including 88% bearers of type person & place, i.e. 6328 were names of persons or place names, which enabled our system to correctly transcribe 6109 bearers of names, while 55%, i.e. 8790 words were those that were not bearers of names and of which our system was able to transcribe 7987 words correctly, giving us an accuracy of 88.19%. sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this work, we conducted our experiment with statistical machine translation tools. We demonstrated how to extract syllables from our input text and perform transliterations of name generators (proper names and places) and other words as units of name in the source language to target language by calculating probability. This transliteration system will prove very useful. By using this approach, we achieved an accuracy of 88.19%. In the future, we will work on remaining name units that were not taken into account in this experiment.

sections.heading: Authors
sections.text: Deepti Bhalla is pursuing her M.Tech in Computer Science from Banasthali University, Rajasthan, and works as a research assistant in the Anglo-Indian Languages Machine Translation System Project, funded by the TDIL Programme, DEITY. She is particularly interested in machine translation in the field of the English-Punjabi Language Pair. She has developed various tools for Punjabi Language Processing. Her current research interests include natural language processing and machine translation. Nisheeth Joshi is a researcher working in the field of machine translation. He is primarily involved in the design and development of assessment matrices in Indian languages. He is also actively involved in the development of MT engines for English into Indian languages. He is one of the experts working with the TDIL Programme, the Department of Electronic Information Technology (DEITY), Govt. of India, a leading organisation providing Language Technology Funding Research in India.

[3] proposed Hybrid Approach for Transliteration from Punjabi to English.
[5] presented conversion system on Punjabi Text to IPA.
[6] presented a novel approach to improve Punjabi to Hindi transliteration by combining a basic character to character mapping approach with rule based and Soundex based enhancements.

[7] have addressed the problem of machine transliteration where given a named entity in Hindi using Devanagari script need to be transliterated in English using CRF as a statistical probability tool and n-gram as a features set.
For this we have used Stanford NER tool [10] which gives us name entities in English text.
